item.title: IMF calls on China to cut industrial subsidies in half — 91 replies — 364.0/hr
item.content:encoded:
IMF calls on China to cut industrial subsidies in half

Open thread • Replies: 91 • Updated: 2026-02-20 09:26 UTC

OP

Early replies (first 3)

61872971
>>61872964
This is a strategic move by the Chinese to kill off the competition in other countries so the Chinese companies can dominate the sectors and then raise the prices

61872974
i'm sure china will get right on that

61872978
jews mad
>>61872971
they can do it forever without raising the prices

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61875517
>>61874965
>How do you think they have such a ridiculous surplus?
by being better than others at everything that matters

61875527
LMAO. Expecting Chinese to stop subsidising their industry is akin to asking Americans to stop eating Burgers.

61875528
>>61875497
Huh no kidding, I hadn’t been paying much attention to that. One thing I will be keeping an eye on is the EU pension crisis and how that’s managed because I personally don’t see a smooth exit from that situation, especially in France. Looking into it, I guess Germany has a similar problem, which I wouldn’t have guessed based on their debt. What’s your take?

61875554
>>61875121
It's between 6 and 8 Yuan so it's still tied to the dollar

61875563
>>61875517
Well, my point was that by managing the currency in order to keep it low, it makes exports more attractive, which results in a huge surplus. If the yuan floated freely, this would eventually correct. A huge trade surplus would mean more demand for the yuan and it would strengthen the currency. However, China doesn’t let this happen. If the currency strengthens or threatens to strengthen beyond what they deem desirable, they weaken their currency by selling yuan or by setting a lower daily exchange rate. This is the advantage of a managed currency, but it also means that it pisses everyone off when their own exports aren’t as competitive or their domestic industries suffer. China claims that they don’t this to the extent that they’re accused of, and it definitely comes in waves of egregiousness, but it seems like they’re back at it.

So yeah, it’s true they’re good at exporting, but their insane trade surplus is in part the result of what I’m describing (an undervalued yuan that is kept undervalued by china’s central bank).

61875564
>>61873590
>call western "social democracies" capitalist
We are 10 times more communist than china... with an extra helping of suicidal democracy

61875572
>>61875527
China doesn't subsidize their industries though
They just do things better and have more affordable standards of living

61875583
>>61873819
Wtf I love China now!

61875617
>>61875554
It can be undervalued and tied to the dollar. Read my post. You seem to think that because a currency’s exchange rate hasn’t changed that it can’t be undervalued or overvalued. That’s not true. Its real value in terms of purchasing power could rise and the central bank could artificially exert downward pressure (which would mean that the exchange rate would stay roughly the same over time). This is exactly what China has been accused of forever, and the issue is that China issue exactly forthcoming with their economic data.

It is obviously tied to the dollar. It is not STRICTLY PEGGED to the dollar. Every day the PBOC sets the exchange rate. The argument is that this rate hasn’t changed and has remained too low for how much demand there is for the yuan.

61875625
>>61875528
Well they're definitely going to bail the pension system out, but it should be kind of mitigated by the military and infrastructure spending because of their domestic industry. Adding money to those sectors should hypothetically cause more younger people to make more money, increasing direct contributions to the pension system. The bet that they're taking is that the spending won't increase inflation as much as it will improve the economic situation, which has some merit because Germany and even the rest of the EU have considerably lower debt to GDP than China or the US, and the currency has been appreciating broadly over the past few years giving them room for increased spending

61875629
>>61875572

Most of them are subsidised. They do not call them as subsidies but different names.

Source: Ran a Business sourcing products from multiple suppliers in China.

61875657
>>61873690
A communist dictator that values his people and his country will absolutely make any system built on jewish corruption look bad.

61875675
>>61875625
Interesting, good take. Definitely a situation to watch, particularly how the bailout happens. Getting a handle on youth unemployment, especially in France, should help, yeah. Realistically, I wonder if the pension system will be continued for much longer moving forward, and I think the French will lose their shit if it’s reformed in any meaningful way.

61876788
>>61872964
China now rises to take the world stage because the west was reckless and retarded with their wealth. They relied on Chinas cheap exports too much and now suffer.

61876792
>>61875124
Yes, the pride comes before the fall. As it always has throughout history.

61876817
>>61875563
It's an interesting theory that borders on coping strategy because it makes currency seem much more important than the worthless shit it is. Yuan floating or not floating does not change the fact that China manufactures everything that's not manufactured elsewhere. The currency that is used in the exchange of goods does not change that fact. The unfloating of yuan would not teleport all the CNC mills, supply chains, and millions of workers into Tennessee or Germany. Currency can ligma balls or be infinitely expensive compared to other currencies, it does not matter. It may seem that it does, but it does not. Fixed currency makes exchange of goods easier, and manufacturers can plan more easily. Exchange rates are annoying, that's true. China eliminated that headache. It's a right decision, but nowhere near the most important decision they made to be the best at everything that matters.

61876956
>>61874655
>the US can literally print the oil price into the ground
it can't actually. Picrel. Being able to produce 70% of the all physical things on Earth give you the ability to print whatever you want WITHOUT inflation.

61877010
>>61876956
midwit take. they avoid inflation by having an iron grip on capital flows. they essentially cheat the impossible trinity model.

61877067
>>61877010
in that case, why don't North Korea/Cuba/Russia print 1 trillion dollars?

61877115
>>61875572
>>61875564
>>61874440

I sincerely hope you're just too young or pol-brained to know any better, but just in case you aren't:

The Chinese state does not give out money (or make sure other financiers are available to give out money) in order to create productive, competitive industry. They do it for 2 reasons:
>It lets them massively overproduce a good (solar panels, EVs, E-bikes, ect...) at a loss in order to crush foreign manufacturing bases and corner the production
>It helps ensure employment.

Half the reason for the boondoggle that has been OBOR is that it meant the Chinese could use central Asia as a dumping ground for all of the dogshit concrete and steel they were churning out at a loss for years. There wasn't an appetite for that much material when they were making it, and they knew it. Export profits were not the point.

The 2nd point is the bigger deal. Basically, for a long time, the deal in China was that so long as the average guy could get a job if he wanted one, and didn't make too much noise, things would get better. The CCP revolution that conquered the country was built on jobless, angry people, and the guys running the CCP did not want to be on the other end of that deal. Therefore, the CCP is willing to subsidize terrible business that are guaranteed to lose money, so long as they can promise jobs. The problem these days is that youth unemployment is high and climbing and the increasingly small share of the Chinese population that is young is more and more dissatisfied with living in a PvE server as the E.

>61876817
>best at everything that matters
What a funny way to say, "polluted their soil, water, and air so thoroughly that not even their party members are able to avoid bone marrow cancer anymore." You would think that they would just incinerate the waste solvents from all the REE processing like Victorian industrialists, but I guess it was 0.000003 RMB cheaper per ton to just dump it into the nearest waterway.

61877159
>>61877115
Ameri fat Kool aid
USAID mental gymnastics

61877162
>>61877115
>OBOR boondoggle
opinion discarded. Remain uninformed and get fucked.
I don't know why low info retards like you are so confident and unaware to the point of spending time typing out that trash.

61877164
>>61877115
>What a funny way to say, "polluted their soil, water, and air so thoroughly that not even their party members are able to avoid bone marrow cancer anymore." You would think that they would just incinerate the waste solvents from all the REE processing like Victorian industrialists, but I guess it was 0.000003 RMB cheaper per ton to just dump it into the nearest waterway.
lol
what a funny way to cope with living in a country that can't make hdmi cables

61877170
>just pollute the water bros!!
>we will break chinese REE monopoly in no time!!!!

61877198
>>61873794
esl subhumans once again on an american website.

61877206
Uh-oh l didn't realize we were all just supposed to go along with the 'china wise like 1000 year old fish' retardation. Fucking spare me. We're talking about a place that has regular catastrophic flooding on a river its people have continually inhabited and farmed for over 3000 years.

>They will scream, they will cry, they will seethe
>but they will never talk about ROI on that rail road/highway combo that was supposed to cross the most economically desolate strip of earth possible to connect "where?" with "who cares?".
>A country that still cannot manage to make etchants more complicated than RCA cleans is gonna totally dominate semiconductors

The really fun environmental whoopsie they did recently was related to cadmium and arsenic uptake. Cotton was being grown in fields contaminated with heavy metals, which is relatively fine since the fibers won't get consumed. Then the order came down to convert cotton fields to grain. The only reason that anyone noticed a problem is that cadmium poisoning causes rapid onset joint pain.

But none of that can top the hilarity of deleting literally millions of infants between 1980 and 2015, then turning around and being utterly shocked at running out of young people.

61877210
>>61877206
we're talking about the only place that can make hdmi cables

61877217
>cotton fields
are all in Xinjiang, which btw produces the absolute best cotton in the world.
>growing grains in Xinjiang
ror
rmao even
do you even read what you wrote and see how retarded you sound?

61877223
>environmental protection
>in 2026
Are we really going to pretend that this matters at all anymore? Look at who's the fucking president. Look at what he's doing to the EPA.

And if Europe wants to have competitive manufacturing again, they'll likely lax regulations too.

I don't like it either, a lot of people are going to get fucked. However competitive manufacturing means slashing prices, which means ignoring everything that doesn't show up on a quarterly report.

61877619
>>61872964
Instead of wasting money on niggers, China subsidizes real businesses that make things?
IMF Jews are seething.

Finding a job

Open thread • Replies: 21 • Updated: 2026-02-20 09:09 UTC

OP

I live near Tampa FL and I'm wondering what are some viable strategies for actually finding work instead of applying to 1000 ghost job listings and praying someone calls me back?

Early replies (first 3)

61875498
>>61875447
Head to your nearest mcdonalds and talk to the manager. You'll be working by end of day.

61875501
>>61875498
I have an engineering degree I'd rather starve and be destitute than work in a factory or retail.

61875515
>>61875498
I'm trying to find stuff other than fucking McDonald's bro

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61875627
>>61875447
Sorry bro FL is literally the worst state in the union for jobs

Our fagnigger governor touts how much money he saves skimming off the annual budget yet the taxes remain insanely high the jobs are shit, the wages are laughable, no fault, right to work state. Its shit but a jewlovers dream

61875634
>>61875447
firm handshake direct eye contact

61875790
>>61875634

61875821
>>61875447
Church. Social network. LinkedIn by making a post asking your hundreds of connections to point you to a job.

61875852
>>61875447
Go to drinking place.
Talk to people.

61875930
>>61875498
This is bullshit boomer advice. McDonalds is full and they only want affirmative action subhumans.

61875971
>>61875447
I've gotten every job I've had by gaming LinkedIn. Add max number of connections each week.
>search for recruiter
>filter by target company
If they add you back send them a message about how you're considering applying to a role at their company and ask them some bullshit questions about company culture or whatever other corporate buzz words are popular at the moment. Hold a conversation instead of being full autistic. Then when you find a role you like start asking questions about the role (even if you already know the answer) with the goal of getting them to put you in direct touch with the hiring manager.

I'm in engineering (real engineering not SWE) so I ask them about NCEES licensure, inter-state reciprocity of license to practice engineering, or some technical questions for the role that HR would never be able to answer.

61876007
>>61875447
walk into a dealership. dont look like a weak faggot. profit.

61876060
>>61875971
I'm just asking about a wage job bro I don't have any qualifications for a engineering job or whatever

61876065
>>61876007

61876138
>>61876060

Menial labor is hiring in droves.
Just do the wagie song and dance.

61877582

item.title: why would anyone live here — 78 replies — 45.5/hr
item.content:encoded:
why would anyone live here

Open thread • Replies: 78 • Updated: 2026-02-20 07:58 UTC

OP

i recently moved to NYC to work for a "lucrative salary" (not really, because this place drains you of all your income) and after working here for 4 months i dont know why anyone would willingly live here

>the entire city smells like rotting shit, cigarette buds and dead animals, not a faint smell, an extremely strong odor that you'll eventually just become nose blind to

>homeless people, fucking everywhere, when i left my apartment there were homeless people sleeping in the hallways of my complex, when you go on walk there are homeless people sleeping on the sidewalk with a PILLOW and BLANKET while regular people walk over them like this is just some normal fucking occurrence (and in this shithole it is) never ever have i seen some shit like this even in the worst of cities ive lived in.

>heroin needles, weed bags, cigarette buds & the occasional dildo just scattered across the city sidewalks, your constantly walking over human shit, broken bottles or dime bags

>rats and rodents EVERYWHERE. il never forget the time i bought a pizza from one of the disgusting street vendors and when i sat down at a table one of the rats were circling my feet trying to climb my leg for a bite.

>the "public transport" system is a just permanent housing for the mentally ill, every time i had to ride the subway i was scared for my life because of all the fucking looneys that inhabit the train systems

this is just off the top of my head, but i think the biggest mindfuck of it all is that its EXPENSIVE to live here its gonna cost you not 50k, not 100k, not 200k, to live comfortably by yourself you need 250K yearly in manhattan. 250k, to live among violent homeless people, 250k to constantly have to walk in rotting shit and roadkill. 250k to have your ears blown out by car horns & niggerbabble, 250k to be forced to smell the most putried scents imaginable i dont know why anyone sane would live here, this place is some sort of social experiment, some sort of anonmoly.

61872828
>>61872797
Go back to your trailer park, pussy

61872853

item.title: Me do asset management & financial planning for a living AMAA — 53 replies — 15.1/hr
item.content:encoded:
Me do asset management & financial planning for a living AMAA

Open thread • Replies: 53 • Updated: 2026-02-20 06:10 UTC

OP

Me do asset management & financial planning for a living AMAA

Early replies (first 3)

61872440
>>61872433
Looks boring af. How haven't you kys'd yourself yet?

61872446
>he doesnt trade his own money to become a player of the game like his clients

61872467
For someone with 200k to invest, what would you do? I’m thinking of a split between SPYI, QQQI, O, and SCHD.

Latest replies (last 30, oldest → newest)

61872998
>>61872888
There are a lot of assets that meet or beat equity markets with CAGR and are low correlation. Some are right in the data here >>61872698

Gold for example has a higher average annual return, better risk adjusted return, and a 0.1 correlation.

61873012
>>61872467
All on btc shorts. Outperform those gay indexes for the next three years in one week

61873080
>>61872467
Why do you focus on yield so much instead of total returns?

It's a lot of US large cap equity exposure with tax inefficiency if it's in a taxable account. You'll get big dividend though.

I like PTY, ASGI, etc for yield personally.

61873145
>>61872998
no it fucking doesn't, in the last 110 years it has returned 5% while the stock market returned 10%

61873184
>>61873145
ik this is probably bait but that's a very silly time period to look at because before we got off the gold standard it was fixed ounces/USD.

Meaning 0% growth for half that period dragging the CAGR way down lol. Doesn't make sense to look at the return pre Nixon shock for that reason.

61873190
>>61872433
if you like uncorrelated risk adjusted-returns you should look at alternative investments.

61873207
>>61873190
Returns are totally dependent on the managers imho, it's a cool class. I'm not a huge fan of the illiquidity personally.

I do like some of them them, especially private farmland/timberland.

Not a huge fan of venture or growth PE, guess I'm lame.

61873214
>>61873207
have you looked into managed futures?

61873220
>>61873080
I use my brokerage as my main savings account. Instead of getting $500/month in a high yield savings account I rather get $1400, 50-75% I could reinvest. But since you do this for a living I'm going to listen and allocate more money for growth rather than yield going forward, and you're right about the taxes, I didn't think too much about that. Thanks!

61873222
>>61873214
I cant believe I forgot about those!

I use the ETFs for simplicity. ISMF/CTA for crisis alpha. I almost went DBMF too, but I prefer the purer systematic trend heavy ones.

Do you have any strong opinions on them?

Seems like extreme negative correlation, like -0.4 with 6-8% CAGR which is completely acceptable if you're rebalancing with a really aggressive equity portfolio. I considered pairing them with TQQQ or SOXL to be a total jackass at once point and pussed out,

61873231
>>61873220
You accept more risk (volatility) for those higher returns, that's the tradeoff. If you are OK with higher risk then you could always choose one of those balanced allocation funds.

AOR for example just rebalances a 60% stock / 40% bond index portfolio.

AOA does the same thing but 80% stock (more risk)

These really are the easy button for people that don't want to self-manage imo.

Probably a good idea to put the portion that's your emergency fund into something boring and very lowvol but decent yield. Check out JPST, that might be a good fit.

61873256
>>61873222
>>61873190
those are the returns for my managed futures program, im a CTA. its great uncorrelated returns but theres a lot of programs that under perform or blow up (-60%+ years). its definitely more liquid than other alternatives.

61873270
>>61873256
Damn dude you're crushing it. What's the time period on those returns?

Mind if I ask what your strategy is?

Any specific managed futures ETFs you like? Are they even close to replicating the actuals?

61873283
>>61873270
thats 20 months of performance trading 8 different futures markets. semi-systematic medium frequency trend following. im not too familiar with the ETFs that track managed futures but they usually focus on the billion dollar CTAs and those programs are lower returns lower risk just trying to be uncorrelated.

61873448
>>61873184
ok, its still not beating the stock market unlike your claim, and if you take the last 3 years out and it drops a lot. That is insane volatility that it doesn't converge after 50 years. Realistically the actual return is maybe 7% and you get very long periods of dogshit ~3%, and for all that volatility it still doesn't match the market.

61873450
I’m currently halfway through finishing my CFP course
Any advice for someone trying to hit the ground running, beyond spamming LinkedIn? Or should I just accept that this job market is going to rape me until I give up hope

61873477
>>61872433
Cant ai just do most of that?

61873686
>>61873477
This. Almost tooka financial advisor job. Then I realized, "why the fuck would anybody talk to a human about this?"

61873827
>>61873686
Cause the AI will tell you something plausible that it thinks you want to hear, and it will partially or mostly hallucinate the data it uses to deliver that response

61873887
>>61872433
Do you hold any bitcoin? What are your thoughts on it and does your firm/company advise on it?

61874040
>>61872561
I am a europoor(in a very poor country) so I dont think i have access to most the stuff you are listing. I can only buy ETFs, I have most my portfolio in a Global market cap ETF some in europe ETF and a little in small cap value international and emerging markets. Also bought a sizable stack of silver sub 30 dollars but its going to be a bitch to sell. I dont invest in bonds since I think that every government will just keep on printing.

61874046
>>61873450
Connections are everything, and the exam will be easier than you think. The classes were hugely valuable, were harder and more useful than my master's degree courses. Most companies will have you try to peddle shit insurance products to friends/family at the entry level it's gross.

>>61873477
>>61873686
Maybe someday, not right now. For what >>61873827 said and because it just sucks at answering niche or complex questions. When I ask it things it usually feeds me flat out wrong answers that would be passable to someone that didn't do any research.

One example is having it try to pick stocks. Gets obliterated by the index funds every time. It's a consistent loser at this because it can't make forward projections and the question is too complicated for it. Tax questions are a horror show too, you'd think it would be good at those.

The main issue with AI in my eyes is that it just doesn't understand humans/human nature. Most of my job is behavioral.

>>61873887
I do, I made a bunch of money in it 2016ish and now build and rebalance a position in my retirement accounts (5-10% allocation).

61874061
>>61874040
Wish I knew more about EU investing, I'm completely specialized for US investing so it's out of my wheelhouse. I only have a handful of expat/foreign clients.

EU bonds have been zero or even negative for a long time. I won't touch them because they don't compensate you for loaning them money, and I can't believe people keep buying them.

Apparently it has something to do with their SIPC insurance equivalent, safer park for cash than a checking account basically because of the federal coverage you get by buying a bond. I haven't looked much into it just what I heard.

61874087
>>61873887
>does your firm/company advise on it?

Forgot to answer this part. We don't buy it in our portfolios, but we do help clients manage the risk associated with it. Some people are believers in crypto so we highlight the risks (volatility, no intrinsic value, etc) and then work with them to figure out how much of their overall investments is a prudent amount to put into that risk asset. I personally cap myself at 10% for both gold and crypto.

Crypto is actually considered speculation instead of investing by most managers. Kind of like commodities/gold/NFTs.

61874261
>>61873448
>its still not beating the stock market
It does in the 26-year backward looking period in the data array from the picture by 30bp. Instead of just pulling 7% out of your booty you could spend 10 seconds doing the present value calculation if you really wanted.


It's about 9.8% annualized if you go all the way back to '71 from now ($39-$5,000). That's definitely nothing to scoff at when constructing a portfolio and hedging equity markets considering the 0.1 correlation.

>That is insane volatility
Volatility is good in a portfolio of non-correlated assets that's rebalanced outside of tolerance bands.

>all that volatility it still doesn't match the market
Almost keeps up with it and doesn't move in the same direction, which is the idea. Non-correlated assets, rebalancing the volatility, and risk-return tradeoff are portfolio construction 101.

61874286
Alright anon, I'm out. Have a great day and I hope every one of you gets to retire early.

PS long nursing homes

61874295
>>61872433
Is there a gap in the asset management & financial planning software market? Seems you are just using an excel sheet there. Is there any way your life could be easier or more automated?

I'm a developer and I like money

61874345
>>61874295
The software is pretty comprehensive and generally way deeper than just an excel sheet, but of course there's an industry spectrum of how deep/detailed the analysis goes by firm and by program.

Some is straight up basically a cash flows projection laid on top of a balance sheet (excel). The people that use this are shitty whole life insurance people.

It's the auxiliary software where the money is at right now it seems. AI that reads trusts using OCR and spits out a summary to help you find issues. Tax software. Stuff like that.

Our software for portfolio management (have used 3) is AWFUL though. That's a big gap for asset management imho.

61876336
>>61874261
Im sorry but your sample size is not big enough. The volatility and nature of the distribution of gold prices (its not normally distributed) means you have to be very careful about inferring information about long term returns. For example if you look at gold as an asset just 5 years ago you get very different conclusions.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ulgqlQWlPbo If the data changes heavily based on the precise dates or periods that you choose it indicates it hasn't converged to an acceptable error margin yet. 7% is a guess at what an average random sample period would be given that they can range from ~3% to ~9% or w/e but idk, im not gonna do your job for you.

A simple sanity check should tell you that an asset that doesn't produce or do much of anything shouldn't outperform real cash generating businesses and companies in the long term.

61877215
Are you Jewish?
